repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
**Problem:** Every time `LanguageTree:parse()` is called with a range, previously parsed injection trees are dropped, and replaced with trees parsed from the new range. Besides being inefficient and preventing injections from taking advantage of incremental reparsing, this also means that when 2+ windows are open into the same buffer, the highlighter will one at a time, meaning the trees of the others get dropped, leading to highlight flickering.

Additionally, when searching for trees to parse or trees to check for validity in `is_valid()`, currently *all* known injection regions are checked, which is inefficient for combined injections with lots of trees.

**Solution:** Track injection ranges with extmarks. This means each region is stored in a sorted BTree, so we can only iterate over the ones we need to access in a given range. This also means that we can keep trees from other ranges, since adding injection trees won't interfere with other tracked marks.

Finally fixes #32660 (for real this time :crossed_fingers:). Related: #22426. Also fixes #35993

---

Summary of changes so far:

- Only edit trees occurring on or after an edit (to adjust the included ranges)
- Use extmarks to track valid regions/trees
- Store either a `Range6` or an entire `TSTree` for a given region (depending on if the region has already been parsed), not both
- Only parse child trees when `range` is truthy; clean up the docs for `LanguageTree:parse()` since some of it is overly confusing/no longer relevant to the current implementation
- Track parsed injection regions using extmarks for better perf, correctness

TODO:

- Incrementally reparse/invalidate trees
- Maybe allow `for_each_tree` to take a `range` parameter?

Putting this up just to track the work so far. There is still much to be done. Feel free to critique as I go along, if you like

comment_data.body:
The point of the `_on_conceal_line` is that conceal_line marks are placed before Nvim needs to know the height of a line. So the `nvim_win_text_height()` call here should work as is. The fact that it doesn't indicates there is a problem.

The `_on_conceal_line` callback also already parses synchronously. Any clue why that is (no longer) sufficient?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1774,6 +1774,9 @@ function M.open_floating_preview(contents, syntax, opts)
     if not opts.height then
       -- Reduce window height if TS highlighter conceals code block backticks.
       local win_height = api.nvim_win_get_height(floating_winnr)
+      -- Synchronously parse the viewport in case highlighting hasn't completed. This will cause
+      -- highlighting to finish, applying conceal lines marks.
+      assert(vim.treesitter.get_parser(floating_bufnr, 'markdown')):parse({ 0, win_height })

comment_data.body:
I notice that this seems to resolve the issue (after removing the parse call from `util.lua`)
```diff
diff --git a/runtime/lua/vim/treesitter/highlighter.lua b/runtime/lua/vim/treesitter/highlighter.lua
index 69f8fd3beb..f14b14108a 100644
--- a/runtime/lua/vim/treesitter/highlighter.lua
+++ b/runtime/lua/vim/treesitter/highlighter.lua
@@ -527,7 +527,7 @@ function TSHighlighter._on_conceal_line(_, win, buf, row)

   -- Do not affect potentially populated highlight state.
   local highlight_states = self._highlight_states[win]
-  self.tree:parse({ row, row })
+  self.tree:parse({ row, row + 1 })
   self:prepare_highlight_states(win, row, row)
   on_range_impl(self, win, buf, row, 0, row + 1, 0, false, true)
   self._highlight_states[win] = highlight_states
```

Is the parse range supposed to be end exclusive? Or could there be an off-by-one error somewhere in this PR? Since it worked beforeðŸ˜…
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1774,6 +1774,9 @@ function M.open_floating_preview(contents, syntax, opts)
     if not opts.height then
       -- Reduce window height if TS highlighter conceals code block backticks.
       local win_height = api.nvim_win_get_height(floating_winnr)
+      -- Synchronously parse the viewport in case highlighting hasn't completed. This will cause
+      -- highlighting to finish, applying conceal lines marks.
+      assert(vim.treesitter.get_parser(floating_bufnr, 'markdown')):parse({ 0, win_height })

comment_data.body:
Interesting :thinking: 

> The `_on_conceal_line` callback also already parses synchronously. Any clue why that is (no longer) sufficient?

I think the new parsing logic introduced some flakiness around parsing the first line maybe(?), which is also causing the flaky failures in the other test below. I'll do some logging; my theory is that the conceal_line parse doesn't set a proper extmark within the parser, since the range is technically empty (row, 0, row, 0)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1774,6 +1774,9 @@ function M.open_floating_preview(contents, syntax, opts)
     if not opts.height then
       -- Reduce window height if TS highlighter conceals code block backticks.
       local win_height = api.nvim_win_get_height(floating_winnr)
+      -- Synchronously parse the viewport in case highlighting hasn't completed. This will cause
+      -- highlighting to finish, applying conceal lines marks.
+      assert(vim.treesitter.get_parser(floating_bufnr, 'markdown')):parse({ 0, win_height })

comment_data.body: Nice, that was also the fix I was thinking of too :+1: Yeah I think due to the reliance on extmarks, the ranges might need to be non-empty now (and maybe they are end exclusive too? but I don't think they should be...)

comment_data.body: Damn, looks like this doesn't fix the flaky highlight_spec test. Changing to `:parse(true)` for debugging doesn't even fix this oddly enough, but reverting 150490d365a37b89d88a0e66ef6ec789bb4eb1c3 does

comment_regular_data.body:
A "Problem" statement will help clarify the goal here. 

p.s. does this close an open issue?
Edited :+1: (feel free to adjust if the wording is awkward)

This PR is now basically equivalent to the existing code; parser and highlighter tests are passing. There is just some weirdness left around conceal lines; they are trying to parse a range at `row == -1` which leads to invalid extmark placements, hence some test failures when TS is enabled for hover windows or popup menu. Looking into it now.

What's left still:

- A logic change to smartly, incrementally invalidate/reparse injected trees. Should be very simple now, hopefully a small change
- Add more info in docs since this is an invasive change
- Tests
- Keep `LanguageTree:set_included_regions()`? (maybe with a stricter API, only accepting `Range6[]` rather than lists of nodes/range4)

ï»¿@zeertzjq  would you mind lending some wisdom here whenever you get a spare moment? for some reason my changes are making `nvim_win_text_height().all == 0`, which causes a test case to fail (related to lsp hover heights shrinking when encountering concealed lines). it is the last failing test case for the PR, but the issue is above my pay grade and I've been losing my hair over it. hopefully you have some insight here, and thank you in advance
I have no idea what's wrong with your PR.
:sob: thank you for looking. i'll do some more investigating.

title: feat(treesitter)!: use extmarks to track injection regions
